name: Volume of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths using unit cubes

skills.name: Calculate the volume of a cuboid when the dimensions are given in the same units

explanations.A: You're close! I think you've calculated the capacity of the tank, but the question asks for the volume of water that is in the tank. Is it completely full?
explanations.B: We need to calculate length x width x height for the volume and the height we need to use is the height of the water. So 2 1/4 x 2/3 x 1 1/5 = 1 4/5. Each measurement was in m so the units will be metres cubed. Answer is 1 4/5 m³.
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied all 4 measurements together. Remember to calculate the volume of a cuboid you do length x width x height. Which 3 measurements do you need to find the volume of the water?
explanations.D: I think you might have found the area of the bottom of the tank so haven't calculated a volume yet. Which height measurement do you need to calculate the volume of the water?

explanations.A: I think you have multiplied all 4 measurements together. Remember to calculate the volume of a cuboid you do length x width x height. Which 3 measurements do you need to find the volume of the water?
explanations.B: You're close! I think you've calculated the capacity of the tank, but the question asks for the volume of water that is in the tank. Is it completely full?
explanations.C: I think you might have found the area of the bottom of the tank so haven't calculated a volume yet. Which height measurement do you need to calculate the volume of the water?
explanations.D: We need to calculate length x width x height for the volume and the height we need to use is the height of the water. So 2 2/3 x 4/5 x 1 3/4 = 3 11/15. Each measurement was in m so the units will be metres cubed. Answer is 3 11/15 m³.

explanations.A: I think you may have calculated the volume of the flower bed and then added the 2 ft³ on. But that is the soil already in the flower bed and we want to know how much more we will need to fill it.
explanations.B: I think you may have subtracted the 2 from the width of the flower bed and then calculated the volume. But the 2 is 2ft³ which means it's a volume of soil, not a length. What should you calculate before you do the subtraction?
explanations.C: The volume of the flower bed is 1/2 x 6 2/7 x 2 1/3 = 7 1/3 ft³. There is already 2 ft³ of soil in there so we need to work out the difference for how much more soil we need. 7 1/3 ft³ - 2 ft³ = 5 1/3 ft³.
explanations.D: I think you have calculated the volume of the flower bed which is a good start. But there is already 2 ft³ of soil in there so how can you work out how much more soil you will need to fill the flower bed?

explanations.A: I think you have calculated the volume of the flower bed which is a good start. But there is already 3 ft³ of soil in there so how can you work out how much more soil you will need to fill the flower bed?
explanations.B: I think you may have subtracted the 3 from the length of the flower bed and then calculated the volume. But the 3 is 3ft³ which means it's a volume of soil, not a length. What should you calculate before you do the subtraction?
explanations.C: I think you may have calculated the volume of the flower bed and then added the 3 ft³ on. But that is the soil already in the flower bed and we want to know how much more we will need to fill it
explanations.D: The volume of the flower bed is 2/3 x 5 3/5 x 2 1/4 = 8 2/5 ft³. There is already 3 ft³ of soil in there so we need to work out the difference for how much more soil we need. 8 2/5 ft³ - 3 ft³ = 5 2/5 ft³.

explanations.A: You have worked out how many cubes would fit into the cuboid but each of these cubes has a volume of 1/8cm³ not 1cm³. If there are 24 cubes each with a volume of 1/8cm³ what is the volume of the 24 cubes and therefore the cuboid?
explanations.B: I think you may have got a little mixed up with the volume of the cubes. The side length is 1/2 cm, not the volume. Check the information in the question to find the volume of the cube so you can then use that to find the volume of the cuboid.
explanations.C: I think you have added the side lengths of the cuboid. Have a look at the dimensions of the cube, how many 1/2 cm could you fit along each measurement? How many cubes will fit into the cuboid? And take note of the volume of each of these cubes, how can you use that to calculate the volume of the cuboid?
explanations.D: As the cube has a side length of 1/2 cm we could fit 4 along the length and 3 along the width. There would be 12 cubes on the bottom layer. The height of the cuboid is 1cm and the height of the cube is 1/2 cm so we could stack them 2 high so there will be 2 layers of 12 cubes. 2 x 12 = 24 cubes. Each cube has a volume of 1/8cm³ so the volume of the cuboid is 24 x 1/8 = 3 cm³.

explanations.A: I think you have added the side lengths of the cuboid. Have a look at the dimensions of the cube, how many 1/3 cm could you fit along each measurement? How many cubes will fit into the cuboid? And take note of the volume of each of these cubes, how can you use that to calculate the volume of the cuboid?
explanations.B: As the cube has a side length of 1/3 cm we could fit 6 along the length and 4 along the width. There would be 24 cubes on the bottom layer. The height of the cuboid is 1cm and the height of the cube is 1/3 cm so we could stack them 3 high so there will be 3 layers of 24 cubes. 3 x 24 = 72 cubes. Each cube has a volume of 1/27cm³ so the volume of the cuboid is 72 x 1/27 = 2 2/3 cm³.
explanations.C: I think you may have got a little mixed up with the volume of the cubes. The side length is 1/3 cm, not the volume. Check the information in the question to find the volume of the cube so you can then use that to find the volume of the cuboid.
explanations.D: You have worked out how many cubes would fit into the cuboid but each of these cubes has a volume of 1/27cm³ not 1cm³. If there are 72 cubes each with a volume of 1/27cm³ what is the volume of the 72 cubes and therefore the cuboid?

explanations.A: I think you have worked out how many cubes will fit inside the cuboid which is a great start, but the cubes do not have a volume of 1cm³. If the side length of the cube is 2/5 cm, then what is the volume of the cube? You can then use this to work out the volume of the cuboid. You will know the number of cubes that fit in it and the volume of each of those cubes.
explanations.B: I think you may have got a little mixed up with the volume of the cubes. The side length is 2/5 cm, not the volume. If you know the side length of the cube, how do you work out the volume of the cube? You can then use this to work out the volume of the cuboid.
explanations.C: As the cube has a side length of 2/5 cm we could fit 3 along the length and 2 along the width. There would be 6 cubes on the bottom layer. The height of the cuboid is 4/5 cm and the height of the cube is 2/5 cm so we could stack them 2 high so there will be 2 layers of 6 cubes. 2 x 6 = 12 cubes. Each cube has a volume of 8/125cm³ ((2/5)³) so the volume of the cuboid is 12 x 8/125 = 96/125cm³.
explanations.D: You're close but I think you've used the volume of the cube as 4/25. 4/25 is the side length squared. If you want volume what do you need to do to the side length of 2/5 ?

explanations.A: As the cube has a side length of 2/3 cm we could fit 4 along the length and 2 along the width. There would be 8 cubes on the bottom layer. The height of the cuboid is 2 cm and the height of the cube is 2/3 cm so we could stack them 3 high so there will be 3 layers of 8 cubes. 3 x 8 = 24 cubes. Each cube has a volume of 8/27cm³ ((2/3)³) so the volume of the cuboid is 24 x 8/27 = 7 1/9cm³.
explanations.B: You're close but I think you've used the volume of the cube as 4/9. 4/9 is the side length squared. If you want volume what do you need to do to the side length of 2/3 ?
explanations.C: I think you have worked out how many cubes will fit inside the cuboid which is a great start, but the cubes do not have a volume of 1cm³. If the side length of the cube is 2/3 cm, then what is the volume of the cube? You can then use this to work out the volume of the cuboid. You will know the number of cubes that fit in it and the volume of each of those cubes.
explanations.D: I think you may have got a little mixed up with the volume of the cubes. The side length is 2/3 cm, not the volume. If you know the side length of the cube, how do you work out the volume of the cube? You can then use this to work out the volume of the cuboid.

explanations.A: Tom is correct, you can do length x width x height to calculate the volume. But take another look at Katie's explanation. If you can find out how many of the unit cubes will fit into the cuboid, and you can find out what the volume of one of the unit cubes is then you can multiply the number of cubes by their volume to find the volume of the cuboid. If the cube has a side length of 1/3 cm then what would the volume of that cube be?
explanations.B: Katie is correct but take another look at Tom's method. Remember to calculate the volume of a cuboid there is a formula for it ; length x width x height.
explanations.C: To calculate the volume of a cuboid we do length x width x height and we can multiply in any order. So Tom's method is correct. We could also find out how many unit cubes would fit into the cuboid and then multiply by 1/27 as that is the volume of one of the cubes. The side length of the cube is 1/3 so the volume is (1/3)³ = 1/27. So Katie is also correct.
explanations.D: I think you may be a little unsure about how to calculate volume. There is a formula to find the volume of a cuboid which is length x width x height. We can multiply in any order. Does that fit any of the methods? We can also find out how many unit cubes would fit inside the cuboid and multiply that by the volume of each cube. If the side length of each cube is 1/3 cm, what is the volume of each cube? Does that match any of the methods?

explanations.A: To calculate the volume of a cuboid we do length x width x height and we can multiply in any order. So Tom's method is correct. We could also find out how many unit cubes would fit into the cuboid and then multiply by the volume of the cube. If the side length of the cube is 1/2 cm then the volume will be (1/2)³ = 1/8cm³. Katie has made a mistake here as she has used the side length instead of the volume so her method is incorrect. Only Tom is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite - Katie has actually used the side length of the cube in her calculation instead of the volume! What is another method we can use?
explanations.C: You're close! Look carefully at Katie's method. She says to multiply the number of cubes by 1/2. But that is the side length of the cube, not the volume. If the side length of the cube is 1/2 cm what is the volume of it?
explanations.D: I think you may be a little unsure about how to calculate volume. There is a formula to find the volume of a cuboid which is length x width x height. We can multiply in any order. Does that fit any of the methods? We can also find out how many unit cubes would fit inside the cuboid and multiply that by the volume of each cube. If the side length of each cube is 1/2 cm, what is the volume of each cube? Does that match any of the methods?
